Topic.Title: Dumbo Impeached-Benghazi

Message.Msg: I can't stop jumping up and down with joy. A pile of poop popped out of me , that's how hard I was jumping up and down but the schadenfreude is well worth the mess on the floor, that I just moved my lazy-boy on top of, I even found a full can of Old Milwaukee under it to toast with. All is well and good in this, the best of all possible worlds.

Message.Title: a burrito proves things are as they are meant to be
Message.Msg: everything works out for the best in this, the best of all possible worlds! Amen! How else could I get a Sirloin Steak & Egg Burrito with Fire Roasted Tomato Salsa prepared and served by poor people who make the minimum wage and who envy me because I can afford such a lavish burrito? I am so thankful God made me a genius and the inheritance was a nice bonus from above. Nothing like good genes and plenty of cash, I always say.

Topic.Title: Loan reserves

Message.Msg: SSHHHHHHH!!!!!! With any really really good luck we get ONE MORE DIP to buy. Just one. A short duck under $10 just for old times? Ahhh, I doubt it either. Decided not turn another bit of temporary position into permanent position. No such thing as too much in the way of long term gains. Particularly when I desperately need a bit of cash outside my brokerage account to start on the actual cabin in my remote hideaway. I spent all my immediately spendable cash money putting in the utilities and prepping the site for construction, and now I don't have a down payment lest I sacrifice my precious investments, and it ain't time right now when the market is experiencing an up kick, but yeah, I'm another one of those looking to build not only ONE house as a temp house/hunting cabin on my land, but another, MUCH MUCH larger when we're done with that one to live in permanently. I need IMC to pay $1.50/sh for Woulfe Mining or something like that, as this would certainly give me more than enough of a down payment for both projects. Remember, the best investment out there is to continue to expand your dwelling over your life until such time as you can fit all your stuff in it, and it represents about 12% to 20% (depending on YOUR risk tolerance) of your wealth (even if multiple dwellings are required, or some made oceangoing) when out of debt. It's sort of risky, but not as risky as being caught without enough real-estate in the right area to feed and house your dependents during a time of depression. Those 1920's bankers wouldn't have been falling like rain if all of them had thought to buy 500 acres of ranch land with some of that money they were #$%$ away. Of course with the luck of some of those chumps they'd have bought in the dustbowl.

Topic.Title: Loan reserves

Message.Msg: P.S. Why isn't this board happier instead of wasting our time with yet more political rhetoric this far from an election cycle? I mean, all us longs put some reasonable gains on the board on Friday, and who cares what happens to shorts until they wantta start sharing their sources so we can emulate the remarkable timing they must have to make ANY money off a stock trading for a fraction of book value. Wanna bet short interest is down by another day at the 15th of May?

Topic.Title: Loan reserves

Message.Msg: Yep, I've been on a parallel path. I sold all of my real estate holdings in 2006 and 2007 (except my primary residence), and in 2010 started accumulating properties again via tax auctions, bank foreclosures, etc. One of the properties is a 4-acre parcel about 1 hour north of San Francisco, a beautiful hillside property in a mostly agricultural town known for cow's milk and eggs. Put in a deep well, and just finishing up the grading plan for a small granny unit (kinda like your cabin) AND a much larger primary residence. The plan is to build the smaller unit, and then wait to build the larger unit at some time in the more distant future. Also, picked up ~21 acres in the Sierra Foothills (gold country) in another very agricultural area. You are spot on, having some land that can actually sustain one's family (whether it be agricultural, streams with fish, cattle grazing, whatever) in the event of a major downturn is critical. Some people say hide in gold, but you can't fill empty bellies with gold nuggets.

Add those unable to differentiate the scent along with the 98% reflexive poop vote and the 70% mostly reflexive "slight movement across a border" crowd and you have plenty enough to elect a poopy President for a Poopy Constituency, You, however, won't be able to enjoy the cesspoll, all because you were handed to someone who had something to DO with a bottle of poop . . . . Mug someone . . . . (a part of the rest of the constituency). One could take the moral from your predicament that even been a closed container of feces isn't too bad, as long as someone can find a use for you. I don't tend to mug people, and wouldn't need a bottle of poop to do it with, so for me . . . . Not worth so much. I say that with no small measure of relief. People who think its there business what other people spend their money on are some of the worst control freaks on the planet.

Topic.Title: rich pub paid $300 for a bottle of my conservative wine

You just don't wanna enter a business where you know you can never hope to compete with he best.
